awd_abstract_narration:
The 2021 EDGE (Enhancing Diversity in Graduate Education) Summer Symposium is a three-day event that addresses mathematical research and professional development.  The Symposium uses a vertical mentorship model to fill in a variety of gaps (academic and non-academic) that are not guaranteed to be filled by other means.  The community built during EDGE programs is the primary mechanism that increases retention, access to professional opportunities, and likelihood that our participants don’t just succeed, they thrive and are propelled  into careers in the mathematical sciences that influence the whole community.

The EDGE Summer Symposium combines research talks, panel discussions, and formal and informal networking events. The EDGE Symposium will bring together (virtually and in-person) 75 mathematicians, primarily an intersection of women and graduate students, and will be hosted by the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis.  Participants of the Summer Symposium discuss cutting-edge research, motivating further discoveries and empowering less senior participants to strive for similar work. These more junior participants also receive indispensable career advice, while more established mathematicians hone their mentoring skills, strengthen their own support network, and deepen their commitment to influencing the next generation of mathematicians. In increasing the number of women who succeed in graduate school and beyond, the Summer Symposium increases the visibility of a diverse collective of mathematicians, inspiring younger mathematicians to persevere and become leaders in the mathematical sciences. Further information about the EDGE program may be found at: https://www.edgeforwomen.org/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The EDGE Program offers comprehensive mentoring and support to women, approximately half of whom are underrepresented minorities, pursuing careers in the mathematical sciences. EDGE activities are designed to provide ongoing support toward academic development and research productivity at several critical career stages.EDGE has garnered wide respect from many in the mathematics community and has been recognized by the American Mathematical Society as an outstanding program that successfully addresses the issue of underrepresented groups in mathematics.

This award supported the 2021 EDGE Summer Symposium, a hybrid event that welcomed the 2021 Summer Program cohort (attended in person) as well as the 2020 Summer Program cohort (attended virtually). Additionally, numerous guest speakers as well as EDGE staff and faculty participated in the conference. 

Attendees of the Summer Symposium discussed cutting-edge research, motivating further discoveries and empowering less senior attendees to strive for similar work. These more junior participants also received indispensable career advice, while more established mathematicians honed their mentoring skills, strengthened their own support network, and deepened their commitment to influencing the next generation of mathematicians. Through all of these activities, new professional connections were made and the EDGE network of professional women mathematicians was expanded and enhanced.

A large majority of participants of the EDGE Summer Symposium are PhD students. While these participants are too early in their career to see the results of the EDGE Summer Symposium, EDGE has a strong track record of supporting its alumni to complete their PhDs. Since EDGE’s inception in 1998, two hundred and ninety-seven women have participated in the EDGE Summer Program and Summer Symposium. Over 90% of EDGE alumni have received an advanced degree or are still persisting in their studies. 

EDGE alumni are in visible leadership positions in allmathematical sectors: over 110 EDGE participantswork in academia or education, 7 work in government, and 43 work in industry. EDGE participants who have completed their PhDs have also served in many leadership roles in our professional mathematics societies —organizing workshops for the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics and the Mathematical Association of America, serving on the executive committee of the Association for Women in Mathematics, and serving as a guest editor for a special edition of the AMS Notices. The EDGE Program has received numerous awards for its success, including the Presidential Award for Excellence in Science, Mathematics and Engineering Mentoring.
